title: Ownership
description: Rust's unique memory management model - the ownership system.
content:
# Ownership

**Ownership** is one of Rust's most important and unique features. This system guarantees memory safety without using a garbage collector.

## Principles

1. **Every value has one "owner"**
2. **There can only be one owner at a time**
3. **When the owner goes out of scope, the value is freed**

## Scope and Ownership

```rust
{  // s doesn't exist here
    let s = String::from("hello");  // s is valid from here
    // use s
}  // s goes out of scope, memory is freed
```

## Move Semantics

```rust
let s1 = String::from("hello");
let s2 = s1;  // s1's value moves to s2
// s1 is no longer usable!
println!("{}", s1);  // ERROR!
```

## Copy Types

Some types are automatically copied (Copy trait):

```rust
let x = 5;
let y = x;  // x's value is copied, not moved
println!("{}", x);  // OK, x is still usable
```

Copy types: integers, bool, char, tuples (if all elements are Copy).

codeExamples.title: Scope and Ownership
codeExamples.explanation: Variable lifetimes are tied to scope. When a variable goes out of scope, memory is automatically freed.

codeExamples.title: Move Semantics
codeExamples.explanation: The String type is not Copy, so when we assign s1 to s2, the value "moves". s1 is no longer usable after this.

codeExamples.title: Copy Types
codeExamples.explanation: Integers and other Copy types are automatically copied, not moved. Both variables remain usable.

codeExamples.title: Blockchain: Ownership of Transactions
codeExamples.explanation: In blockchain, transactions should be consumed when processed. Rust's ownership system enforces this - once a transaction is moved, it can't be used again, preventing accidental double-processing.
